title: London 2017 board members bid to oust chairman Ed Warner
title_page: London 2017 board members bid to oust chairman Ed Warner | Daily Mail Online
text:
The future of London 2017 could be thrown into chaos with board members for the event preparing to issue a vote-of-no-confidence in chairman Ed Warner.
There is increasing concern that Warner is not the correct person to head up the biggest athletics event to be held in this country since the London Olympics and things are set to come to a head at a board meeting on Friday, a source told Sportsmail.
Warner, Chairman of UK Athletics, is the highest ranking individual in the sport in Britain and appeared before a Parliamentary culture media and sport select committee into blood doping on Tuesday.
There is increasing concern that Warner is not the correct person to head up the biggest athletics event
He attracted some criticism for failing to report at the time a story he heard of Qatari officials handing out brown envelopes on the eve of the vote for the 2017 world championships.
He admitted that ‘in hindsight’ he should have reported the rumours, told to him by an IAAF council member he refused to name, at the time.
This is seen as a potential embarrassment for London 2017 but the board are also concerned about what they perceive as Warner’s failure to line up a major sponsor with the event less than 18 months away and the sport enduring its least marketable time in history with its miserable landscape of doping and corruption.
During Warner’s tenure at the head of UKA Sainsbury’s cut short its multimillion-pound, four-year deal to sponsor British Athletics last year while Aviva ended its support in 2012.
Money is short and the backdrop to this financial precariousness is a power struggle between London 2017 managing director Sally Bolton who is in charge of the operations and Warner and Niels De Vos, chief executive at UKA. Some members of the board have expressed disquiet about the lack of distinction between London 2017 and UKA, the governing body for the sport in Britain.
It is thought they considered issuing a vote-of-no-confidence against Warner late last year but according to a source are ‘very determined to see it through’ this time.
